verses.text: And the people of Israel again did what was evil in the sight of the LORD, so the LORD delivered them into the hand of the Philistines for forty years.
verses.comment: Repeated cycle of Israel's disobedience and oppression as seen throughout Judges.

verses.text: And there was a certain man of Zorah, from the clan of the Danites, whose name was Manoah. His wife was barren and had not borne children.
verses.comment: Like other significant figures, Samson's birth is miraculous to a barren woman.

verses.text: And the angel of the LORD appeared to the woman and said to her, 'Behold, you are barren and have not borne children, but you shall conceive and bear a son.'
verses.comment: The angel of the LORD is a recurring messenger in the OT, often associated with God's presence.

verses.text: Now therefore, be careful and do not drink wine or strong drink, and do not eat anything unclean.
verses.comment: These are Nazirite requirements (Num. 6) and instructions to the mother.

verses.text: For behold, you shall conceive and bear a son. No razor shall come upon his head, for the child shall be a Nazirite to God from the womb, and he shall begin to save Israel from the hand of the Philistines.
verses.comment: Nazirite vow's requirements (Num. 6). Samson 'beginning' to deliver Israel—fully completed later.

verses.text: Then the woman came and told her husband, saying, 'A man of God came to me, and his appearance was like the appearance of the angel of God, very awesome. I did not ask him where he came from, and he did not tell me his name.'
verses.comment: 'Man of God' is a term used for prophets/Moses. The angel's appearance is described as fearsome.

verses.text: But he said to me, 'Behold, you shall conceive and bear a son. So then, do not drink wine or strong drink, and do not eat anything unclean, for the child shall be a Nazirite to God from the womb to the day of his death.'
verses.comment: The requirements are restated by the woman; adds 'to the day of his death.'

verses.text: Then Manoah prayed to the LORD and said, 'O Lord, let the man of God whom you sent come again to us and teach us what we should do for the boy who will be born.'
verses.comment: Manoah asks for further guidance, shows his faith and sense of responsibility.

verses.text: And God listened to the voice of Manoah, and the angel of God came again to the woman as she was sitting in the field; but Manoah her husband was not with her.
verses.comment: God repeats His appearance to the woman rather than to Manoah, underlining her role.

verses.text: So the woman ran quickly and told her husband, 'Behold, the man who came to me the other day has appeared to me.'
verses.comment: Demonstrates the woman's initiative.

verses.text: And Manoah arose and went after his wife and came to the man and said to him, 'Are you the man who spoke to this woman?' And he said, 'I am.'
verses.comment: The angel's identity is confirmed.

verses.text: And Manoah said, 'Now when your words come true, what will be the boy's rule of life and his work?'
verses.comment: Manoah seeks practical instructions for raising the promised child.

verses.text: And the angel of the LORD said to Manoah, 'Of all that I said to the woman let her be careful.'
verses.comment: The instructions are for the woman to follow.

verses.text: She may not eat anything that comes from the vine, neither let her drink wine or strong drink, nor eat anything unclean. All that I commanded her she must observe.'
verses.comment: Instructions repeated for emphasis.

verses.text: Then Manoah said to the angel of the LORD, 'Please let us detain you, and we will prepare a young goat for you.'
verses.comment: Hospitality to divine messengers was customary.

verses.text: And the angel of the LORD said to Manoah, 'If you detain me, I will not eat your food. But if you prepare a burnt offering, then offer it to the LORD.' For Manoah did not know that he was the angel of the LORD.
verses.comment: The angel refuses the meal but directs him to worship God.

verses.text: And Manoah said to the angel of the LORD, 'What is your name, so that when your words come true we may honor you?'
verses.comment: Requesting the angel's name hints at seeking authority and honor.

verses.text: But the angel of the LORD said to him, 'Why do you ask my name, seeing it is wonderful?'
verses.comment: 'Wonderful' (Heb. 'pili') means too marvelous/incomprehensible.

verses.text: So Manoah took the young goat with the grain offering and offered it on the rock to the LORD, to the one who does wondrous things. And Manoah and his wife were watching.
verses.comment: A burnt offering is made, and God acts miraculously.

verses.text: For as the flame went up toward heaven from the altar, the angel of the LORD went up in the flame of the altar while Manoah and his wife watched; and they fell on their faces to the ground.
verses.comment: Supernatural departure identifies the messenger as divine.

verses.text: The angel of the LORD did not appear again to Manoah and his wife. Then Manoah knew that he was the angel of the LORD.
verses.comment: The full realization of the angel's identity.

verses.text: And Manoah said to his wife, 'We shall surely die, because we have seen God.'
verses.comment: A common biblical fear that to see God means death.

verses.text: But his wife said to him, 'If the LORD had meant to kill us, he would not have accepted a burnt offering and a grain offering from our hands, or shown us all these things, or now announced such things as these.'
verses.comment: The woman displays greater theological understanding.

verses.text: And the woman bore a son and called his name Samson. And the boy grew, and the LORD blessed him.
verses.comment: Samson is related to the Hebrew word for 'sun.'

verses.text: And the Spirit of the LORD began to stir him in Mahaneh-dan, between Zorah and Eshtaol.
verses.comment: 'Mahaneh-dan' means 'camp of Dan'; the Spirit's empowerment begins Samson's story.
